item.description:
NEW HAMPSHIRE SERIES:
Mt. Waumbek and Mt. Cabot ... Two 4,000-Footers!

EVENT ORGANIZER: Julie Moran. Please contact me here with your thoughts and ideas about this trip: jmmoran {{AT}} nycap.rr.com, Mobile 518-281-5882 (please, no phone calls prior to the event). FINISH YOUR NH 48 4,000 LIST WITH US!


ESSENTIAL TRIP DETAILS

Difficulty: This is Day Two of the "Cabot-Waubeck Weekend"; today's hike to Mt. Starr King and Mt. Waumbek is 7.2 miles RT, about 2,600' of vertical climb; at a 1.25-1.5 mile / hour pace this is about a 5- to an 5 3/4-hour hike.

Trailhead Start Time, Day Two: 9 a.m.

CLICK HERE: Google Maps Trailhead Directions, Distances (link) from where I'm planning to camp along Zealand Road, to the the meetup location at the Starr King Trailhead at the end of a short unnamed forest road just opposite the end of Route 115A, off of U.S. 2, Jefferson, NH).


This hike invariably passes over Mt. Waumbek's sister peak, Mt. Starr King, which has a distinctive summit clearing featuring a standing fireplace from an old inn, and a resident pair of grey jays.



TRIP SUMMARY / UPDATES (08/23/2010 7:30 p.m.): This trip is a cross-posted event with Hiking Mates CHALLENGE, New England Hiking Meetup and the 4 Seasons Hiking Group, in conjunction with the previous day's hike to Mt. Cabot. These hikes are are weather dependent ... please stay close to the website for updates. NOTE: This is a dog-friendly hike (i.e., Mike is going!). At this point, the rain date will be September 6th.

The plan includes travel along the Starr King Trail, named for the 19th Century notable Reverend The plan Starr King which many gentry visited in the late 1800's. It is also a segment of the Cohos Trail which runs the length of Coos County and is infrequent marked with Cohos Trail signs.


ESSENTIALS TO BRING: Flash light AND head lamp, food / snacks / at least three bottles of water, first aid items, sunscreen, bug repellent. Wear multiple layers of synthetic materials for warmth; trekking poles may be helpful gear for this hike.


RESEARCH ESSENTIALS:


AREA OVERVIEW -- TRAIL DESCRIPTIONS AND TRIP REPORTS
Link, Area Overview, Peakbagging the 4000 Footer Mountains of New England

MT. WAUMBEK
Link, SummitPost Page
Link, Appalachian Mountain Club Page
Link, Hike the Whites
Link, Wikipedia


Link, Trail Description - Starr King Trail

Link, Up-To-Date Trail Conditions



NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

WEATHER AND OTHER SUDDEN EVENTS CAN CAUSE SUDDEN CHANGES TO OR CANCELLATION OF THIS EVENT. YOU MUST CHECK BACK TO THE MEETUP.COM SITE OFTEN FOR UPDATES TO ANY HIKING MATES CHALLENGE EVENT. BY ATTENDING YOU'VE AGREED THAT YOU'VE READ INFORMATION PRESENTED HERE AND AT OUR GUIDELINES -- CLICK THE "ABOUT" LINK AT LEFT.

See you there! Julie.
item.how_to_find_us: Look for the Green Honda Element ...
